Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 212, \u00a7 3.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 212, § 3, as the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000 and the injuries giving rise to this action occurred within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 223, § 1, as the events giving rise to this action occurred in Suffolk County, Massachusetts, specifically at 500 Commonwealth Ave, Boston, MA 02215.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 85, \u00a7 11B.proposition: Plaintiff was lawfully traveling in a marked bike lane and adhered to all relevant Massachusetts traffic laws, including Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 85, § 11B, which governs the rights and responsibilities of bicyclists.

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 90, \u00a7 14.proposition: Defendant’s actions violated Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 90, § 14, which requires operators of motor vehicles to use caution when opening doors into traffic and prohibits opening a vehicle door unless it is safe to do so.

Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a defendant is liable for negligence where they owe a duty of care to the plaintiff, breach that duty, and the breach proximately causes the plaintiff to suffer damages.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states the elements the plaintiffs must prove for their negligence claims under Massachusetts law: breach of a duty to use reasonable care, actual loss (damages), and causation (that the defendant’s negligence caused the loss). Although the court ultimately finds the plaintiffs failed on causation, its articulation of these elements directly supports the cited general negligence proposition for Massachusetts law.
Glidden v. Maglio, 430 Mass. 694, 696 (2.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiffs argue that they presented sufficient evidence to warrant a trial of each of their negligence claims. With respect to each such claim, the plaintiffs bear the burden of proving that the defendant committed a breach of the duty to use reasonable care, that the plaintiffs suffered actual loss, and that the defendant’s negligence caused their loss. See Restatement (Second) of Torts § 281 (1965); J.R. Nolan & L.J. Sartorio, Tort Law § 204 (2d ed. 1989). Causation is an essential element of that proof.”

*Boylan v. Everett*, 172 Mass. 453 (1899.raw_text: *Boylan v. Everett*, 172 Mass. 453 (1899) (holding that motorists must exercise care when opening doors to avoid injury to others);
*Boylan v. Everett*, 172 Mass. 453 (1899.proposition: (holding that motorists must exercise care when opening doors to avoid injury to others);
*Boylan v. Everett*, 172 Mass. 453 (1899.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt concerns liability as a ‘keeper’ of a dog under a Massachusetts statute and whether certain facts required a ruling, as a matter of law, that the defendants were keepers. It does not mention automobiles, motorists, doors, or any duty related to opening vehicle doors. Therefore, it does not support the proposition that motorists must exercise care when opening doors to avoid injury to others; the proposition appears to be mismatched to this case.
*Boylan v. Everett*, 172 Mass. 453 (1899.relevant_excerpt: "The bill of exceptions in this case does not state that it contains all of the evidence material to the issue involved, and the question whether the defendants were the keepers of the dog, within the Pub. Sts. c. 102, § 93, was a question of fact for the jury... While the acts recited may be evidence of keepership... it cannot be said that they are conclusive."

*Gillespie v. Seydell*, 332 Mass. 108, 1.raw_text: *Gillespie v. Seydell*, 332 Mass. 108, 110 (1954) (recognizing a motorist’s duty to avoid acts that endanger bicyclists);
*Gillespie v. Seydell*, 332 Mass. 108, 1.proposition: (recognizing a motorist’s duty to avoid acts that endanger bicyclists);

*Giordano v. Duarte*, 397 Mass. 479, 482.raw_text: *Giordano v. Duarte*, 397 Mass. 479, 482 (1986) (noting that violations of statutes may constitute evidence of negligence);
*Giordano v. Duarte*, 397 Mass. 479, 482.proposition: (noting that violations of statutes may constitute evidence of negligence);
